fields.headline: Discrimination in Iran's temporary marriage law goes unchecked

webTitle: Rupert Murdoch owns too many newspapers, says Harriet Harman

fields.bodyText: The shadow culture secretary, Harriet Harman, has said Rupert Murdoch owns "too many newspapers" in the UK and has called for legislative change to address this. Harman said the forthcoming 2015 Communications Act presented an "opportunity to take action to deal with difficult, historical problems which have been left unaddressed for too long". She added that the green paper which the government will publish by the end of the year setting out the scope for the act needs to examine ways of curbing Murdoch's power. "The accumulation of too much power led to a sense of invincibility and impunity," Harman said, speaking at a Westminster Media Forum event about the upcoming communications legislation in Whitehall on Tuesday. "Murdoch owns too many newspapers and had it not been for the phone-hacking scandal the government would have waved through his bid to take control of the whole of BSkyB. Both Ofcom and Leveson are looking at ownership. It is clear that there needs to be change," the Labour MP added. "The malpractice and illegality which has been exposed by the Leveson inquiry was never just 'one rogue reporter' or a few bent policemen. It is a symptom of an underlying structural problem." Harman was also candid about the failings of the Labour government she was part of when it came to courting Murdoch. "People have also said: 'But you were in government for 13 years – why didn't you do something about it? You were too close weren't you?'," she told delegates. "When we were in government, it was the case that many senior figures did become too close to News International and Murdoch." However, Harman said this was a direct result of the mauling the Labour party received during the 1992 general election, which damaged its performance at the polls. "The answer to that lies in what happened before 1992. We put in our 1992 manifesto what we believed was necessary: that we should 'establish an urgent inquiry' by the Monopolies and Mergers Commission into media ownership, and – if the press failed to deal with abuses of individuals' privacy – to implement the statutory protections recommended by the Calcutt report," she added. "Because we were committed to tackling media monopoly and introducing a robust press complaints system, the Murdoch press was determined to stop us getting into government and not a day went by without on every issue, his papers battering us. "So as we approached 1997, we – in Tony Blair's words in his famous 'feral beasts' speech – turned to 'courting, assuaging and persuading the media... after 18 years of opposition and the, at times, ferocious hostility of parts of the media, it was hard to see any alternative'." • To contact the MediaGuardian news desk email editor@mediatheguardian.com or phone 020 3353 3857. webTitle: NHS Commissioning Board to take over NHS IT strategy

fields.bodyText: Responsibility for NHS IT strategy could fall to the NHS Commissioning Board from next year. Alan Perkins, the resources and transition director at NHS Connecting for Health, told the public sector efficiency expo in London that the new arrangements "are going to be established in 2012 for implementation in April 2013" subject to parliamentary process and the health and social care bill getting royal assent. The NHS Commissioning Board would replace the current lead on NHS informatics, NHS Connecting for Health, and provide a "whole range of things from policy through to strategy, to delivery and even ownership of some systems". The NHS Commissioning Board, which currently exists as a special health authority, would also commission IT for delivery on a national basis from a separate "lean organisation". Perkins said that where there is a need for a single IT system across the NHS nationally, the DH will continue to provide it, but that the department intends to stimulate a "vibrant healthcare marketplace" for technology locally - "quite a significant change from where we have been in the past", he added. "For those local systems, the thinking is that each provider will be responsible for their own requirements, although providers might choose to work together and share systems, securing better value for money." Policy around health and social care informatics will be governed by a small team within the Department of Health, Perkins said. This article is published by Guardian Professional. webTitle: Indian state elections deal blow to Rahul Gandhi's political ambitions

fields.bodyText: Rahul Gandhi, the crown prince of Indian politics, suffered a serious setback to his ambitions after voters handed the Congress party a string of defeats in crucial state elections. In five state polls, Congress secured a victory only in the politically insignificant north-eastern state of Manipur, while in India's most populous state, Uttar Pradesh, the party trailed in fourth place. Gandhi, who had staked his political future on reviving his party's fortunes in the northern state, was not the only loser: Mayawati, the tough female chief minister from the "untouchable" Dalit caste, also suffered a humiliating defeat. Mayawati's party had been at the centre of a string of corruption scandals, while her administration had drawn criticism for spending lavishly on public parks with giant statues of herself and other party leaders. Congress initially sought to deflect the blame from Gandhi, but he later appeared outside his mother Sonia's Delhi home to accept his part in the defeat. "I accept responsibility for the fact that we did not perform well. After all, I was the main campaigner … the Congress party fought well, but the result is not good," the 41-year-old said. There was little doubt that the result in Uttar Pradesh, where Rahul had staked his personal prestige and unleashed an aggressive campaign in a bid to revive the party, was a major blow for the young leader. The state has historical significance for the Nehru-Gandhi political dynasty. During the past hundred years, six generations from the family have fought and won elections in Uttar Pradesh, with three of them ruling India as prime minister, including Rahul's father, Rajiv Gandhi. Rahul Gandhi was being touted as the fourth if the Congress party, currently in power in Delhi, were to win the next parliamentary poll due in 2014. A good performance in Uttar Pradesh would have clinched the issue for him. The winner in Uttar Pradesh was the regional socialist Samajwadi party led by a father-son duo. The media often contrasted the low-key style of the son, Akhilesh Yadav, who has a master's degree in environmental engineering from Sydney, with Gandhi's combative posturing. During the final phase of the campaign, Gandhi publicly tore up a list of promises made to the voters by Yadav, saying they were worth nothing. "But unlike Rahul, Yadav inspired greater confidence and trust amongst upper-caste voters who wanted to get rid of Mayawati," said the political analyst Smita Gupta. Analysts have now begun to predict that the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty will have to wait longer than 2014 for its next prime minister. "I am going to stick my neck out and say that Rahul Gandhi will opt out of the prime ministerial race now," said NDTV's Barkha Dutt. Uttar Pradesh was not the only worry for the Congress. The party suffered shock defeats in both Punjab and Goa, while it was deadlocked with its main national rival, the BJP, in the hill state of Uttarakhand. Besides Gandhi's future, the big question now is how these election results will impact on the prime minister, Manmohan Singh, and his Congress-led coalition government, which has been widely criticised for poor governance and corruption, and for its failure to push ahead with much-delayed economic reforms. Much will depend now on the attitude of the Samajwadi party, the winner in Uttar Pradesh, which supports the government at the centre. Paradoxically, after the setback to Gandhi, Singh may find he has more room to execute policies that improve his administration and revive India's sagging economic growth. "Singh's opponents in both the government and the party will now stop demanding constantly that Rahul replace him as prime minister," said Gupta. "This will strengthen the prime minister's hand."

webTitle: Rush Limbaugh and the Republicans' vote-losing sex phobia | Michael Wolff

fields.bodyText: What is a slut? What does Rush Limbaugh mean when he says "slut"? Do we see each other as sexual archetypes and vote accordingly? "Anybody who has several sexual partners in a year is committing spiritual suicide," David Brooks wrote a few years ago in one of his Times op-ed columns, in about as forthright a declaration of conservative sexual revulsion as you're likely to get. "He or she is ripping the veil from all that is private and delicate in oneself, and pulverizing it in an assembly line of selfish sensations." In other words, in the conservative world, sluttiness is binary: you are or you aren't. Although Brooks is correct enough to include men here – "he or she" – it is probably truer that he mostly means women. His formulation is about fragility and weakness (pulverized) and veils. It's the ladies who are most at risk from sluttiness. Brooks, along with Charles Murray, and more recently joined by Rick Santorum, apply a disapproving sociology to show that sexual permissiveness has not only a vast negative moral dimension, but is harmful to the commonweal: people who have a lot of sex are a problem demographic. Rick Santorum's position on sex and how it should be confined is strictly Catholic in an old-time sense. It seems to have surprised just about everybody that he's been able to bring it back with such gusto – he's made birth control an issue! He cannot be "born-again" because Catholics don't go in for that, but he certainly has a born-again zeal and a convert's militancy (rightwing fundamentalists are not classically partial to Catholics, but he seems to have captured an impressive number of diehard protestant hearts). The New York Times ran a curious recent profile of Santorum pointing out that his wife, Karen, had had a long-time relationship with an older man, to whom she wasn't married, who was, to boot, a well-known abortionist. Whatever happened between her and her former boyfriend, and later, her and Rick, seems to have drawn a battle line between her former life and their current one. They both seem to have been fortified by rejecting and now demonizing a certain behavior, and returning to the most rigid and proscribed Catholicism. She repented. Rush Limbaugh is the opposite of Brooks and Santorum, both who seem quite non-sexual. Whereas Rush seems debauched: sated, flabby, flushed. He and Newt Gingrich are in this other conservative mold: they are the bad boys (a different category from bad girls). There are, of course, their many wives and, for Rush, the pills. Rush, we know, has a life full of excess and indulgence – and perhaps, though it is not that easy to imagine, sensual pleasure. In his attack on birth control advocate, Sandra Fluke, Rush hooked the word "slut" to the word "prostitute". I suppose, historically, in a Dickensian sort of world, being the former could lead, or was thought to lead, to the latter. But now, they're two vastly different categories of sexual activity. But obviously not to Rush. It is, I think, reasonable to trust what Rush says. All his utterance seem spontaneous and from some horrifying but genuine core. This is, undoubtedly, why he is so popular: he's unfiltered. It's an electrifying id. In other words, he probably does think that women who have a lot of sex, or perhaps anything more than a minimal amount, are "whores". And whores, in this usage, seem to have sex not just for money, but for deranged, subversive, and anarchic reasons. This is an old-time view that has mostly been badgered out of liberal men, but that the conservatives have somehow been able to forthrightly hold onto: good girls and bad girls. Karen Santorum going from bad to good seems to be among Rick Santorum's proudest accomplishments. Rush, we might imagine, has spent more time with bad girls than with good girls and, indeed, might well bear a grudge against the women who have, in his eyes, led him astray. The point has been crystallized by Limbaugh and the Republican field: the sexual world is a terrible threat. But the reverse is also true: if conservatives see a liberal world of extreme sexual goings-on, liberals look back with awe and mockery, too. Santorum, let's face it, seems sexually puzzling. He would likely make a sexually active nation quite uncomfortable. (Likewise, David Brooks, on his part, has always seemed to me, in his Sunday morning show appearances, to be an odd, furtive, hidden, quite alarming figure.) Mitt Romney has benefited from the Santorum contrast. But in a general election, I think Mitt's sexual basis will be judged more critically. The plastic issue will be have to be overcome. The sense that a candidate is having sex is a much more powerful and positive attribute than the sense that he is not. (Bill Clinton, most obviously.) That is, actually, the corner the Republicans have gotten themselves into now. For some time, the conservative subtext has been to suggest that the liberals were less flesh-and-blood than the visceral Republicans. One was fey, the other strong. One snobbish and remote, the other popular and direct. The message here was simple: Republican men are men. The present field of Republican men, together with Rush's anger at liberals for having sex, recasts these roles. The liberals, after a long time in the wilderness, are emerging as the much more sexy bunch.

fields.bodyText: NOW THE TEACHER IS AWAY, ALL THE KIDS BEGIN TO PLAY Considering some members of the fawning English press pack are so enraptured by 'Arry Redknapp they saw nothing untoward about serenading him Marilyn Monroe-style with a rendition of 'Appy Birthday at a recent press conference, it was only going to be a matter of time before the Tottenham and future England manager was linked with the vacant manager's job at Chelsea. So it came as no great surprise this morning when 'Arry was quoted coyly denying having any interest in one of world football's most lucrative gigs. "It would be difficult. I wouldn't be able to come back to north London," guffawed the man who is so loyal he once took a sabbatical from Portsmouth to relegate Southampton and then go back again. "So no, I will pass on this one," he added, no doubt in a bid to appease his nephew Frank Lampard, who – poor results aside – seems to have been doing a perfectly adequate job co-managing Chelsea for some months now. Of course, seeing as the club's Russian owner Roman Abramovich is famously as thick and difficult to read as a copy of James Joyce's Ulysses, football hacks have been forced to speculate feverishly and almost exclusively without foundation about who might succeed Andre Villas-Boas beyond the obvious handful of usual suspects. And considering he once worked with Jose Mourinho, manages a team that plays attractive passing football and has done more to advance the careers of promising Chelsea youngsters in recent months than any actual Chelsea managers in recent memory, it's small wonder Swansea City boss Brendan Rodgers' name has cropped up in dispatches. "If any of our fans are wondering about me and Chelsea, they need not panic. I am trying to build my career and not destroy it," said the Norn Irish manager, who either genuinely doesn't want the job or is cleverly forcing his way on to Abramovich's radar by deliberately playing hard to get. webTitle: BBC boss says Sky does not give CBBC and CBeebies prominence on EPG

fields.bodyText: A senior BBC executive has accused BSkyB of reneging on its obligation to give public service channels such as CBeebies and CBBC "due prominence" on its electronic programme guide. BBC director of policy and strategy, John Tate, said CBeebies, the BBC's pre-school service, is now 13th on the EPG list of children's channels on Sky, with CBBC in 14th. Above it are channels such as Nicktoons, Boomerang and six Disney services. Speaking at a Westminster Media Forum seminar about the upcoming communications green paper in Whitehall on Tuesday, Tate claimed the current situation was "counter intuitive" and "wrong for the British public". "The work that goes into our channels could not be larger in terms of UK-originated content," he added. He said the BBC was worried about a situation where "due prominence is not respected". Speaking at the event after his session Tate said the current situation was "ridiculous" and called on the government to look at tightening up the definition of due prominence. "When you look at the channels above CBBC and CBeebies then you realise they don't have the earthy UK material we do," he said. "Sky crows about its commitment to UK content so it should be doing something about this. We need a new framework for due prominence and Sky needs to show goodwill and some common sense." Tate's comments were refuted by Sky's director of policy and public affairs, David Wheeldon, who said at the event the existing regulatory model built around a public service broadcaster such as the BBC was "out of date" because it failed to properly recognise the contribution of commercial companies. "We follow a very rational EPG policy at Sky which is very heavily regulated," he said. "CBeebies has a higher share on Sky where it's not at the tip of the EPG than it does on Virgin [Media] where it is at the top of the EPG," Wheeldon added. Sky is obligated to provide "due prominence" to public service channels on the EPG according to a code of practice policed by Ofcom. However, the broadcaster does have some discretion and Ofcom does not currently have the power to prescribe positioning on the EPG. The broadcasting minister, Ed Vaizey, has suggested this could change. In January he told the Oxford Media Convention that the 2015 broadcasting green paper will suggest that broadcasters are rewarded with a higher slot on EPGs if they commit to transmitting more public-service programmes such as news and children's shows. • To contact the MediaGuardian news desk email editor@mediatheguardian.com or phone 020 3353 3857. webTitle: Bradley Wiggins retains overall lead in Paris-Nice race

fields.bodyText: While Bradley Wiggins retained the lead in the Paris-Nice "Race to the Sun" at the finish at Lac de Vassivière in the Limousin in seamless style, a possible threat to his ambition of winning on Sunday hove into view. As widely expected, the Spaniard Alejandro Valverde won the uphill sprint, scooping up a 10-second time bonus that lifted him up the standings to 20sec behind the Briton. Before his ban for doping the Spaniard was virtually unbeatable in this type of finish. There are at least four more stages where he has a chance of winning, so he will have plenty of opportunity to claw back more seconds. "It was really hard today," said Wiggins, the Team Sky leader. "Everybody was knackered." After Monday's unexpectedly tough stage to Orleans, Tuesday was more routine, a three-man escape given enough latitude to inspire faint hope they might last to the finish but kept sufficiently within reach to be scooped up in the final kilometres. Wiggins's Team Sky kept the peloton rolling along until the road began to rise to the finish, at which point Valverde's Movistar – managed by the same group of directors who ran the legendary Banesto team of Miguel Indurain – took over. In the sprint the Spaniard did well to hold off the fast-finishing Australian Simon Gerrans, one of Wiggins's team mates at Sky until this year, when he moved to the new Australian set-up GreenEDGE, who, like Sky, have close links to the national team. It was straightforward stuff but Valverde's is a contorted story, like that of his fellow Spaniard Alberto Contador. Valverde spent almost four years as one of the best specialists at hilly one-day races and short stage races, all the while denying any links with the blood doping ring Operación Puerto, unmasked in 2006. One of the blood bags was labelled Piti, apparently the name of his dog; another Valv. Eventually a connection was established through DNA testing and after a lengthy appeal process he was banned in 2010. He returned at the start of this year, hungry for success, although redemption will be harder to find. Wednesday's stage looks anything but simple on paper, with two second category and four third category climbs in the 111 miles through the Cantal and Aveyron, with another uphill finish in the town of Rodez. It is not massively steep but the ascent lasts 2.5km, with a third category prime 1.5km from the line. It will suit Valverde, who will again be looking to shave at least 10sec from his deficit. To avoid that happening, Sky may well let an escape have its head, in the hope that some of its number get to the finish to scoop up the time bonuses. That in turn, could force the Spaniard and his team to show their hand.

webTitle: Lewis Moody, fearless Englishman, can at last give his body a break | Robert Kitson

fields.bodyText: The outpouring of genuine affection for Lewis Moody from all quarters of the game speaks volumes. Not every retiring England captain is guaranteed a standing ovation but there have been few more popular players inside or outside the dressing room since the dawn of professionalism in the mid-90s. The announcement of the 33-year-old flanker's enforced exit from the fray deprives us of a man who thought nothing of hurling his body where others feared to look, let alone tread. Not for Moody the easy crutches of self-preservation or selfishness. His former captain Martin Johnson summed up his qualities better than most. "When I look back at playing with Lewis it always brings a smile to my face – it was never dull. He was one of the most committed guys I ever played with and had a complete disregard for his own physical wellbeing. It's sad that he has had to retire but he should be remembered for a great career and someone who never gave less than 100% for his club and country." A tally of 71 caps, seven Premiership titles for Leicester and two Lions Test caps do not, as Johnson hints, tell the entire story. Nor did the final, acrimonious World Cup campaign to New Zealand which ended so messily. Better, perhaps, to dwell on the annus mirabilis of 2003 when his soaring lineout take famously set up the drive from which Jonny Wilkinson kicked Australia to defeat in the World Cup final. Moody was writing a column for the Guardian at the time and, clearly, this would be a first-person piece to grace any scrapbook. I vividly remember turning up at the Manly Pacific Hotel the following lunchtime to assist Lewis with his composition. It was a triumph of optimism over bleary-eyed reality. The author, along with everyone else, had been up all night and had the tell-tale weary grin of a man struggling to recall his own name. Hunter S Thompson would have appreciated the hazy recollections printed the following day. Moody's gift, though, was to survive and thrive in a ferociously intense top-level sport for 16 years without exhibiting a shred of malice for anyone or anything. He relished the physical contact almost as much as he loved galloping off in search of it. He might as well have played with the words "No Regrets" tattooed across his forehead; even after a dozen operations he retained an almost child-like enthusiasm for a game which caused him no end of pain. As England captain he was decent, courteous, polite and wholly committed, without once pretending to be Mike Brearley. As a player, particularly in his early days, he was a fly-half's waking nightmare. He was also loyal to his mates, even when they retold embarrassing stories at his expense, The all-time favourite has to be his failure to pay an overdue gas bill while living in a student house in Leicester. He had opened the letter, seen the words "Outstanding Balance" and thought they were writing to congratulate him. There was also the time he argued Argentina was definitely in Europe, not to mention the occasion he revealed his mum had phoned to tell him to close the windows because it was raining. Genius. For all this, and more, Moody will be fondly remembered whatever he does with the rest of his life. He has also become a standard-bearer for colitis sufferers, having gone public about his lengthy struggle with the condition. Finally he can relax on a Saturday afternoon, although that may not be as easy as it sounds. "Rugby has been my life for such a long time now, it is scary to imagine what it will be like without it," he confessed on Tuesday. Having played just 44 minutes of Premiership rugby for Bath this season, however, his body will certainly relish a break. In the end it was a shoulder operation following his last appearance against Worcester in November that proved the final straw for a player whose injury woes rivalled Wilkinson's. "Sometimes it's just luck. Sometimes maybe I trained too hard, though I can't speak for Jonny. We both went through a hideous run of injuries and it does affect you on all sorts of levels," he told me before Christmas. "But it's the nature of the beast. I'll look back at my career and say that I still managed to play a lot of rugby. I'll never look back and say I wish I'd tried a bit harder. I'll always know I achieved as much as I possibly could have done. That said, I don't think I appreciate yet quite how much I will miss it." Or, in turn, how much people will miss him.

I vividly remember turning up at the Manly Pacific Hotel the following lunchtime to assist Lewis with his composition. It was a triumph of optimism over bleary-eyed reality. The author, along with everyone else, had been up all night and had the tell-tale weary grin of a man struggling to recall his own name. Hunter S Thompson would have appreciated the hazy recollections printed the following day.

Moody's gift, though, was to survive and thrive in a ferociously intense top-level sport for 16 years without exhibiting a shred of malice for anyone or anything. He relished the physical contact almost as much as he loved galloping off in search of it. He might as well have played with the words "No Regrets" tattooed across his forehead; even after a dozen operations he retained an almost child-like enthusiasm for a game which caused him no end of pain. As England captain he was decent, courteous, polite and wholly committed, without once pretending to be Mike Brearley. As a player, particularly in his early days, he was a fly-half's waking nightmare.

He was also loyal to his mates, even when they retold embarrassing stories at his expense, The all-time favourite has to be his failure to pay an overdue gas bill while living in a student house in Leicester. He had opened the letter, seen the words "Outstanding Balance" and thought they were writing to congratulate him. There was also the time he argued Argentina was definitely in Europe, not to mention the occasion he revealed his mum had phoned to tell him to close the windows because it was raining. Genius.

For all this, and more, Moody will be fondly remembered whatever he does with the rest of his life. He has also become a standard-bearer for colitis sufferers, having gone public about his lengthy struggle with the condition. Finally he can relax on a Saturday afternoon, although that may not be as easy as it sounds. "Rugby has been my life for such a long time now, it is scary to imagine what it will be like without it," he confessed on Tuesday.

Having played just 44 minutes of Premiership rugby for Bath this season, however, his body will certainly relish a break. In the end it was a shoulder operation following his last appearance against Worcester in November that proved the final straw for a player whose injury woes rivalled Wilkinson's. "Sometimes it's just luck. Sometimes maybe I trained too hard, though I can't speak for Jonny. We both went through a hideous run of injuries and it does affect you on all sorts of levels," he told me before Christmas. "But it's the nature of the beast. I'll look back at my career and say that I still managed to play a lot of rugby. I'll never look back and say I wish I'd tried a bit harder. I'll always know I achieved as much as I possibly could have done. That said, I don't think I appreciate yet quite how much I will miss it." Or, in turn, how much people will miss him.
fields.headline: Lewis Moody, fearless Englishman, can at last give his body a break
fields.trailText: Robert Kitson: The frighteningly committed flanker's enforced exit from the fray deprives us of a man who thought nothing of hurling his body where others feared to look, let alone tread

webTitle: Geneva motor show: aggressive newcomers pile pressure on old order

fields.bodyText: In the massed metallic glare of the Geneva motor show, dozens of car manufacturers try to distinguish themselves from competitors in a carousel of press conferences. Every quarter of an hour, two stands spring to life with a variety of presentational tricks, although thumping middle-of-the-road techno and glamorous assistants appear to be the main publicity device. Outside the doors of the cavernous show hall, in the European car market, the reality is less glitzy. Manufacturers are slugging it out for sales amid slumping demand. At the Rolls-Royce event, the chief executive talked proudly of having no desire to be on "every street corner and in every supermarket parking space". But that is the daily reality for the big carmakers at Geneva, including the established European names such as Fiat, Peugeot, Renault and General Motors's Opel and Vauxhall. They are scrambling for berths at car parks and side streets with aggressive newcomers led by Hyundai and Kia of South Korea. Unveiling its latest model next to the Rolls-Royce stand, Kia talked of the launch establishing the company as "a leading automotive brand in Europe". Mark Fulthorpe, analyst at IHS Automotive, said the emergence of Hyundai and Kia had "squeezed" their more venerable competitors. "Over the past three and four years they have become significant players in the volume market, offering the kind of prices that were the domain of General Motors and Peugeot historically. It is squeezing their market share in a stagnant marketplace in western Europe, which feeds back to the manufacturing sector. It makes the issues even more pointed for some older, established factories." According to IHS, this is exacerbating a production glut that is forcing GM to consider shutting the Ellesmere Port plant with the loss of 2,800 jobs. Analysts believe Europe produces 1.2m cars too many per year. The show is an imposing and impressive spectacle, but the industry has to get smaller.

webTitle: Through the Language Glass [Book Review] | GrrlScientist

fields.bodyText: I was surprised to learn that the Russians recognize two different colours of blue, синий (siniy; dark blue) and голубой (goluboy; light blue), whereas the ancient Greeks didn't have any words at all for blue. In fact, if you've read either of the great epics, Iliad or Odyssey, you'll notice that the poetically eloquent Homer had an unexpectedly sparse colour vocabulary. Does this mean that Homer lived in a relatively colourless world? These intriguing observations led British statesman and Homeric scholar, William Ewart Gladstone, to "launch a thousand ships of learning" when more than 150 years ago he proposed that the Greeks were partially colour-blind. This peculiar hypothesis has had a profound effect on the development of three academic disciplines and triggered a debate that continues to this day: Does the language you speak affect or reflect how you perceive and think about the world? This recasting of the nature/nurture debate has kept scholars engaged in verbal arm-wrestling contests to this very day, a theme that author Guy Deutscher explores at length in his book, Through the Language Glass: Why The World Looks Different In Other Languages [2011: Arrow Books; Guardian Bookshop; Amazon UK; Amazon US]. The first section of the book, entitled "The Language Mirror", provides an overview of the practical reasons why words for individual colors appear in a consistent order across human languages. Words for black and white appear first since night and day are the most obvious events in a human's daily life and they present the strongest contrasts. The word for red then follows, since blood is red, and this is the next most important colour as humans regularly engage in warfare, hunting, childbirth and other bloody exercises. Colour names for yellow and green emerge later in many cultures due to the influence of agriculture and the need to specifically signify ripe or unripe grains and fruits. Then finally, the word for blue typically pops up. This orderly semantic progression sets the stage for a prolonged examination of whether our mother tongue affects our colour perception. For example, if the sea is "wine-coloured" as Homer asserted, or if there is no word-name distinguishing green from yellow or green from blue in a particular language, can the speakers of that language perceive these colours? A separate section containing colour plates anchors this discussion, but overall, I found the shades of grey in this line of argument to be tedious and circular. Further, how the brain processes neural colour input is far more complex than Deutscher ever lets on, although he briefly revisits his colour idea at the end of the book to let us know that he probably shouldn't have discussed the colour example at all. Ho hum. The second section of the book, "The Language Lens", segues into an investigation of word gender (or type) in languages. Some languages do not have gender at all (e.g. the Finno-Ugric branch), whilst some are gender neutral (e.g. English), others have masculine, feminine and neuter genders (the Romance and Germanic languages) whilst still others have a plethora of additional genders, such as human/animal/canine/vegetable/drinks/liquids/mineral, etc. After introducing and attempting to explain the logic of gender assignment for particular words (an impossible task to do properly), the author then asks whether the gender of an object's name word affects how we think about those objects? Deutscher, a native Hebrew speaker, illustrates this idea using an example translated from Hebrew: Out of the masculine window I can see the masculine trees and on them the birds, which are feminine regardless of the accident of their anatomy. If I knew more about (feminine) ornithology, I could tell by looking at each bird what biological sex she was. I would point at her and explain to the less initiated: 'You can tell she is a male because of that red spot on her chest and also because she is larger than the females.' And I would not feel there was anything remotely strange about that. [p. 204] Is that so strange? This is no more strange than ships retaining their feminine gender in English until, well, the publishing industry formally neutralised that charming little holdout in previous decade or so. Deutscher goes on to discuss a number of psychological experiments designed to get at this fundamental gender/perception question. For example, native Spanish speakers are more likely perceive bridges (el puente; masculine gender) as being particularly big, strong or dangerous whilst native German speakers are more likely to perceive bridges (die Brücke; feminine gender) as elegant, fragile and slender. The second half of the book, particularly Deutscher's discussion of gender and perception, was far more interesting and compelling than his prolonged exposé on colour, in my opinion. But it is a relief that, in the end, Deutscher concludes with what most of the rest of us already knew: neither the Sapir-Whorf hypothesis (language determines one's worldview) nor the Pinker hypothesis (language has no effect on one's worldview) can fully answer this nature (brain) versus nurture (culture) debate. In short, it's a little of both. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. Guy Deutscher is an Israeli linguist and an honorary Research Fellow at the School of Languages, Linguistics and Cultures in the University of Manchester. He is a former Fellow of St. John's College, Cambridge and of the Department of Ancient Near Eastern Languages in the University of Leiden in the Netherlands. Through the Language Glass, his second general audience book, was included on the shortlist for the 2011 Royal Society Winton Prize for Science Books. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. twitter: @GrrlScientist facebook: grrlscientist email: grrlscientist@gmail.com

webTitle: Chanel turns gloom to glamour at Paris fashion week – with Superman's help

fields.bodyText: A month of catwalk shows will draw to an end in Paris with no happy ending in sight. The vacancy at Dior remains unfilled, while the designers Raf Simons and Stefano Pilati, handed their P45s under the glaring spotlight of catwalk season, have been forced to take their final bows under a crossfire of rumour and denial. Such was the backstory to the Chanel show, which brought the fashion industry to the Grand Palais on the penultimate day of Paris fashion week. Six weeks ago, designer Karl Lagerfeld turned part of this building into a plane interior, complete with an above-the-clouds view projected beyond the rows of small oval windows, for the set of his Chanel Couture show. This time, Lagerfeld transformed the domed glass building into the Fortress of Solitude, the sparkling crystalline lair of Superman. The floor was thickly covered with glinting white-grey sand. Polished matchstick slivers of amethyst and smokey quartz, tall and angular as catwalk models, were arranged in chic piles between the benches. In pride of place on the front row was Katy Perry, sporting the exact bluebottle hair shade of the cartoon Lois Lane. Was Karl Lagerfeld about to save Planet Fashion? But heroes, it seems, are rather last season; right now, fashion is all about the bad guys. This was a dark, moody Chanel collection that made no attempt to lift the brooding gloom that has engulfed the catwalk shows. Why cheer people up when brooding can be so glamorous? The breakout stars of the Chanel catwalk were the gem-encrusted eyebrows – handmade for the show by the legendary Parisian embroidery house of Lesage – that served to make the models look both fed up and spectacular. Lagerfeld appears to have decided that what a downcast fashion industry needs is not cheering up, but a way to give frowning a bling makeover. Showmanship aside, the material impact of a Chanel collection is twofold: in the silhouette it promotes, and in the accessories. The line was slim, rather than skinny, with volume in the dropped shoulders and in the geometric mouldings of knits and coats. Glitter tweed, a Chanel classic, gave a mineral glint to jackets that had sportswear styling in their half-elasticated waists and oversized hoods, while full skirts were worn over slim velvet trousers. Standout accessories included ankle-strap sandals with crystals prettily encrusted around the heel, and a new line of miniature bags in classic Chanel shapes that will ensure packed-out boutiques from Beijing to Buenos Aires. It was a celebration of the dark arts of fashion, as practised by its master. But – as if to assure the industry that not all is doom and gloom – Lagerfeld added one special ingredient to lighten the mood of the show. A very cute three-year-old took a catwalk turn, carrying a small quilted bag. Take one well-dressed small child, and add a Chanel handbag: this is a man who knows what his women want.

webTitle: Sun, sewage and algae: a recipe for success? | Damian Carrington

fields.bodyText: There's not much that's more renewable than sewage. So the idea of turning human waste into algae and then into biofuel is an attractive one and is now going to be put to the test on a commercial scale in southern Spain. The €12m project will see the sunny skies of Cadiz beaming down on open ponds in which algae suck up the nutrients from the waste water. If all goes to plan over the next five years, the plant will produce about three tonnes of algae a day from 10 hectares of ponds, enough to run about 200 vehicles. The project is led by Aqualia, the third largest private water company in the world, with six other technology and academic partners providing expertise. The European Commission has provided €7m of the €12m funding. Aqualia's Frank Rogalla says the project would turn the sewage treatment facility from a consumer of energy to a producer of energy, very much like the fuel-cell technology I wrote about last week. First, much of the organic matter will be anaerobically digested to produce methane, another fuel source. This is already done on in some tropical countries and for special waste waters, such as that from breweries. The reason for the pre-treatment is so the algae don't have to battle it out with bacteria for the organics. Instead, the carbon dioxide produced alongside the methane is pumped back into the waste water, to feed the algae. A key advantage of the proposal is that the waster water is already full of the nutrients - nitrogen and phosphorus - that the algae need to grow. "We would get the nutrients for free, when today we get paid to destroy them," says Rogalla. He says 30% of the costs for commercial algae growers is buying in nutrients. The algae will not be specially selected strains but instead what grows naturally in the ponds. To use specialised strains would require a closed system, to avoid contamination, which would make the operation very expensive, says Rogalla. Once the algae is harvested and the oils separated to produce biofuel, the remaining organic matter will be burned to generate electricity, as Thames water in the UK are doing. So the operation will produce enough methane to power 400 vehicles (the fuel is commonly used to power buses and trucks in Spain and being tested in the UK), biodiesel for 200 other vehicles and electricity. Rogalla claims that no-one is yet producing tonnes of algae per day, and neither is Aqualia, yet. But if they can, at a reasonable cost, then they will have demonstrated where there's muck, there is indeed brass.

webTitle: FBI offers $1m reward in search for ex-special agent missing in Iran

fields.bodyText: The FBI has offered an award of up to $1m for information leading to the location of a former special agent who disappeared in Iran five years ago. Robert A Levinson vanished on Kish Island, a Persian Gulf resort, in March 2007. He was 59 at the time. Formerly an FBI agent, Levinson was working as a private investigator when he disappeared. His family and US officials say he was investigating cigarette smuggling for a private client at the time of his disappearance. In December, a video of Levinson surfaced showing him alive, if gaunt, a year earlier. Levinson addresses the camera from inside a concrete cell, where he claims to have been held for three years. He said he had been treated well, but implored US authorities to co-operate with his unidentified captors. "I need the help of the United States government to answer the requests of the group that has held me," Levinson said at the time. "Please help me get home. Thirty-three years of service to the United States deserves something," he added. Levinison's wife and seven children received an email last year containing photographs of him wearing what appears to be an orange prison uniform and with a full beard. While federal agents were able to trace the emails back to Afghanistan or Pakistan, they were unable to pinpoint their exact source. On Tuesday, the FBI issued a statement reading: "The Federal Bureau of Investigation will hold a press conference to announce a reward of up to $1,000,000 for information leading directly to the safe location, recovery and return of Robert A Levinson. Robert A Levinson is a US citizen and former FBI Special Agent who disappeared from Kish Island, Iran, five years ago on March 9, 2007." The agency announced the reward at a press conference at the FBI's field office in Washington, DC. Officials in Iran have denied any knowledge of Levinson's disappearance. President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, during a 2010 trip to the US, said his government was willing to co-operate in the investigation. Last year, the secretary of state, Hilary Clinton, indirectly referred to the case, saying the US had evidence Levinson was alive.

On Tuesday, the FBI issued a statement reading: "The Federal Bureau of Investigation will hold a press conference to announce a reward of up to $1,000,000 for information leading directly to the safe location, recovery and return of Robert A Levinson. Robert A Levinson is a US citizen and former FBI Special Agent who disappeared from Kish Island, Iran, five years ago on March 9, 2007."

The agency announced the reward at a press conference at the FBI's field office in Washington, DC.

Officials in Iran have denied any knowledge of Levinson's disappearance. President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, during a 2010 trip to the US, said his government was willing to co-operate in the investigation.

webTitle: Securing the future benefits of technology

fields.bodyText: The UN's specialised agency for information and communication technologies (ICTs), the International Telecom Union (ITU), will hold a World Conference on International Telecommunications (WCIT-12) in December. The aim of the conference is to review the global treaty widely credited for creating the basis of today's connected world, thus the international regulatory framework governing all ICT technologies. The conference comes at a time when technology is having a major impact on economic and social development, and represents a once-in-a-generation opportunity to improve it even further. The treaty under review is known as the International Telecommunication Regulations, or ITRs. It provides governments and industries across the globe with the necessary frameworks for bringing variety and competition to their telecommunications and ICT markets. Telecom regulations opened the door in the 1990s for mobile and the internet technologies. They have stood the test of time but need to adapt to the rapid technological innovations and address critical issues such as cybersecurity. Cyberthreats are on the rise and the risk of cyberwar is very real. But there are no superpowers in cyberspace. In a connected world we are as strong as our weakest link. We can only achieve global solutions through a global framework that promotes – for example – the secured sharing of information and expertise, more effective early warning systems to mitigate cyberrisks, and developing effective resilience across society. The WCIT-12, which is being convened at the request of our 193 member states, will discuss these issues. We have the depth of experience that comes from being the world's longest established intergovernmental organisation and we've been carrying ITU's essential role from the days of the telegraph right through to the modern interconnected world. The right to communicate has been central to the ITU's mission since its origins. Many feel that the time has come to build on the success of the ITR treaty and pave way for creating a fully inclusive information society over the next decade, one that ensures the world's people can gain equitable and affordable access to voice, video and data. Governments and the private sector have complementary roles. Governments shape policy and regulation in consultation with all stakeholders, and the private sector delivers services and infrastructure. Together, ultimately, they implement. WCIT will express the common will of ITU's major stakeholders – its government and private sector membership – and we'll continue to ask for input and feedback. The conference should find win-win solutions that will act as a positive catalyst for the future development of ICT, to benefit all countries and every aspect of people's social lives. webTitle: Homelessness charities seek donations of suits to help people back to work

fields.bodyText: Men and women are being urged to donate any unwanted suits cluttering up their wardrobes as part of a national drive to help homeless people in the UK get back into work. A major barrier facing homeless people trying to get a job is having nothing clean or smart to wear for an interview, so suitmaker A Suit That Fits has teamed up with three homelessness charities to encourage donations. Anyone handing over a suit will be given a £50 gift voucher that can be spent on bespoke tailoring at the retailer. Until 26 April suits can be donated to the Suit for Success campaign, which will then be distributed to homelessness charities Amber, Broadway and Emmaus who will pass them on to those in need. The items can be handed into individual stores, or a number of other locations listed on the website, or arrangements can be made to collect them from corporate outlets. Each of the charities involved offer work and learning outreach programmes to equip members with the skills and confidence they need to get a job and fully support themselves. But they find that members often have nothing suitable to wear to their interview which affects their confidence and can ruin that crucial first impression. By providing people with a smart, clean suit, the company wants to make the process easier. There is little financial help for those needing a hand to buy clothing or pay for travel costs from either government or other sources. In April 2011 several pots of government funding were replaced by the Department of Work and Pensions with the Flexible Support Fund (FSF) – a fund which gives Jobcentre Plus Districts greater freedom to tailor back-to-work support to individual and local need, giving Jobcentre Plus advisers and managers discretion to decide how to help individuals. There is no exhaustive list of needs that may be met by the FSF, but examples could include travel costs, tools or training and even clothing for interviews or specialist items required once work is obtained, such as heavy-duty boots for construction workers. The new fund is estimated to be worth about £147m nationally but there is limited information about it in the public domain and some claimants have complained that the application process is time-consuming and bureaucratic. Warren Bennett, co-founder of A Suit That Fits, said: "Wearing a suit has a massive effect on confidence – especially when looking for work. If we can help individuals to feel more confident when going to interviews, and therefore increase their chances of getting a job, then the campaign will have been a resounding success." Amber has three residential centres which each accommodate 30 young people who are referred by various organisations including the prison service, probation, Youth Offending Teams, social services, local authorities, hostels, addiction treatment agencies, other voluntary organisations as well as family and friends and self-referrals. A recent beneficiary is unemployed Jared, 20, who came to Amber in August 2011 after spending two weeks living on the streets and following a period of "sofa surfing". Jared said: "I recently attended an army selection weekend and interview; for the interview I used the money I had saved since being at Amber to purchase a suit as I wanted to make a good impression."

webTitle: Olympian qualifies for London 2012 at age of 70

fields.bodyText: Almost half a century may have elapsed since he competed in his first Olympic games, but Hiroshi Hoketsu is poised to enter the record books after qualifying for London's 2012 Olympics at the age of 70. The former company director qualified for Japan's Olympic equestrian team after finishing in first place in the International Equestrian Federation's Asia-Oceania dressage rankings. He must now await a formal decision on his selection for individual dressage. It would be Hoketsu's third Olympics, having competed in his native Tokyo in 1964, aged 23, and again in Beijing in 2008, where he was the oldest Olympian. Now living in Aachen, in west Germany, Hoketsu said he was very pleased to have qualified, especially as his horse, Whisper, a 15-year-old mare, had suffered some problems. She is "a little bit old, but still a good age", Hoketsu, who will be 71 at the time of the London Olympics, told the Associated Press in a telephone interview. If he does compete, Hoketsu will increase the record he set in 2008 for being the oldest Japanese Olympics competitor, but fall a fraction short of taking the record for the oldest Olympian ever, held by Swedish shooter Oscar Swahn, who won a silver medal at the 1920 Antwerp Games aged 72, his sixth medal in three games. Hoketsu, who moved to Aachen after retiring as a director of the multinational pharmaceutical company Johnson & Johnson eight years ago to train full-time, has been riding Whisper for five years but had ruled out competing in the 2012 Olympics because of the horse's health. "It started with the front legs and no one was able to determine the cause of the horse's health problems. It was very complicated," he said. The problems began in February last year and three different vets were unable to find a cure until eventually there was a diagnosis of tendinitis. "I had totally given up on trying to go to London," he said. "But then in mid-November a friend introduced me to a good vet and one month later I was training again, and in January I started competing again. The horse's recovery was a miracle." Hoketsu, who started riding at the age of 12, finished 40th in the showjumping event in Tokyo. Throughout his long equestrian career he has won several national championships and qualified for the 1988 Seoul Olympics, but did not compete following quarantine issues with his horse. He was a named reserve for the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, though not called. At Beijing he was part of the team that finished ninth, and in the individual dressage competition he was placed 35th. "In London, I hope to do a little better," he said. "I didn't do that well in Beijing because they had that big screen in the hall and my horse just hates to see that moving screen." Old and young Oscar Swahn, 72 The oldest ever Olympic competitor won silver for shooting in the 100m running deer event at the 1920 Olympic Games in Antwerp. He was selected again in 1924 but illness forced him to withdraw. Lorna Johnstone, 70 Britain's oldest Olympian, known as the Galloping Granny, competed in dressage at the 1972 Munich Olympics. Galen Carter Spencer, 68 The American won silver in archery in the 1904 games in St Louis. Paul Cerutti, 65 Competing for Monaco in 1976, the trapshooter was disqualified after failing a drugs test. Ian Millar, 61 The Canadian showjumper competed in his ninth Olympics in Beijing in 2008, taking silver in the team event. Dimitrios Loundras, 10 The youngest identified entrant competed at the 1896 Athens Olympics for Greece, winning a team bronze in gymnastics. Katy Stoddard

webTitle: How technology-driven teamwork can fuel social change

fields.bodyText: The economist Joseph Schumpeter long ago argued that crises were seedbeds of innovation and entrepreneurship. In today's economic crisis, we certainly need all the innovation we can get, particularly in addressing big social challenges, such as rising youth unemployment and the care needs of an ageing population. As a social investor that invests in and supports organisations that are using digital technology for social good, it is inspiring to see just how many social enterprises are using technology as a tool for innovation. We're seeing an ever-increasing tide of inspiring individuals who recognise the potential of technology to support new forms of collaboration, untap and reorganise resources across communities and create new opportunities for social participation. It is also interesting to see that the most effective examples of positive social change result from collaboration across the public, private and third sectors. FutureGov is an example of a social enterprise that is using technology to address a big social challenge. Recognising that there are numerous agencies involved in the complex and challenging world of child protection, FutureGov's Patchwork project used social media to put children and their families at the centre of the professional support networks, bridging the communication gaps between agencies. Patchwork is an app that enables any member of a family's team to administer their case, breaking down organisational silos in public services and also empowering frontline staff and the family to maintain an up-to-date picture of who's involved. The Patchwork prototype was co-designed in Lichfield, Staffordshire, with a project team that included children's charity Barnardo's, technologists, policy advisers and family representatives. They developed a concept for how social technology could contribute to keeping children safe. It is the buy-in and collaboration from the senior leadership teams across the various child protection agencies and support services that has been the key to Patchwork's success. As part of the prototype phase, FutureGov developed a change management methodology to ensure the technology influenced wider attitudinal change among public agencies working with children. An investment by Nominet Trust, the social enterprise I run, is helping FutureGov to develop the prototype into a service that can be scaled across all 400 UK local authority areas. Nominet Trust funding has also been able to help Cockermouth Centre for the Third Age, on the edge of the Lake District, to develop a "virtual centre". Using an online platform, GPs can refer patients who are lonely, mildly depressed or have mobility issues to the volunteer-run centre which offers company, help with shopping, training on the internet and generally a shoulder to lean on. In the first three months of the Cockermouth project, emergency admissions to hospital were down by 143 on the previous year. Its founders were asked by the Department of Health to write a paper on how this model for GP engagement could be replicated nationally. A key factor in the success of both projects is the early collaboration between the public, private and third sectors. Herein lies the challenge: we need to find new opportunities for cross-sector collaboration that draw on the imagination, expertise and networks across industry, government and social enterprise to develop co-designed and scalable solutions to big social challenges. These projects demonstrate how digital technology can help us to redesign how we address social challenges. At a time of financial constraint, we need to be particularly innovative in our use of resources. Technology gives us the opportunity to think differently, develop new social connections and reorganise resources across communities. When approached by nimble, enthusiastic social entrepreneurs who are prepared to test out genuinely new approaches, the role for public managers is to embrace these new forms of collaboration. • Annika Small is director of the Nominet Trust, which invests in projects where digital resources are being mobilised to create positive social change

webTitle: Portrait of Margaret Beaufort, mother and grandmother of kings, is unveiled

fields.bodyText: A rare Tudor portrait of Margaret Beaufort, the formidable grandmother of Henry VIII, has been unveiled by the historian David Starkey at Hever Castle in Kent. Beaufort married three times – a fourth marriage when she was only a child was annulled – and outlived all her husbands. Her ambition helped propel both her son and her grandson to become kings of England. Starkey has called Beaufort the most powerful woman in England of her day: after her son was crowned she signed her letters Margaret R. She was descended from Edward III through John of Gaunt, and was also a scholar and author who founded two Cambridge colleges. She lived just long enough to see Henry VIII crowned; Starkey has suggested that overeating at the coronation banquet may have contributed to her death. Although she appears meek and nun-like in the painting, she was one of the wealthiest women in the country. The apparent simplicity is deceptive: she is portrayed holding an illuminated prayer book, a luxury object, against a sumptuous silk cloth of state. The picture, recently acquired by the castle to add to an important collection of Tudor portraits, was painted long after her death in the reign of Elizabeth I, possibly copying an original which is now lost. It will be placed on display as Hever, the childhood home of Anne Boleyn, Margaret's granddaughter-in-law, reopens for the season.

Although she appears meek and nun-like in the painting, she was one of the wealthiest women in the country. The apparent simplicity is deceptive: she is portrayed holding an illuminated prayer book, a luxury object, against a sumptuous silk cloth of state.

The picture, recently acquired by the castle to add to an important collection of Tudor portraits, was painted long after her death in the reign of Elizabeth I, possibly copying an original which is now lost.

It will be placed on display as Hever, the childhood home of Anne Boleyn, Margaret's granddaughter-in-law, reopens for the season.
fields.trailText: Historian David Starkey shows painting of 'the most powerful woman in Tudor England' at Hever Castle
fields.headline: Portrait of Margaret Beaufort, mother and grandmother of kings, is unveiled

webTitle: Gulf Keystone slumps 22% on doubts about Exxon Mobil bid

fields.bodyText: A day after HSBC began coverage of Gulf Keystone with an underperform rating, the oil explorer's shares have fallen sharply. It's more a question of good timing than cause and effect as far as HSBC is concerned, however, since the company is now being undermined by doubts about whether Exxon Mobil would bid for the business, something which has helped support the shares in recent weeks. Exxon is keen to expand in the Kurdistan region of Iraq, where Gulf Keystone has operations, and there had been speculation the US oil giant would snap up the company to help fulfill its strategy. But the Iraqi government has set a deadline of the next few days for Exxon to explain its intentions in Kurdistan, a semi-autonomous region where Iraq believes some of oil deals agreed are illegal. If Exxon steps back, that takes some of the takover froth out of Gulf Keystone's shares. They are currently 22% lower - down 73p at 266p.

webTitle: Osborne's child benefit changes offend basic notions of fairness

fields.bodyText: David Cameron is apparently suddenly all of a fluster about the "cliff edge" over which some current recipients of child benefit will plunge next January, when the government's policy of withdrawing the £20-a-week payment from higher-rate taxpayers comes into force. Because it's linked to whether or not there's an earner in the household who takes home more than the £42,745 threshold for paying 40% income tax, families where both parents go out to work have an in-built advantage. They can earn £80,000 between them (so long as it's evenly divided), while hanging on to their child benefit. If mum (or dad) is at home looking after the kids, however, the benefit will be withdrawn when the household's total income hits £42,745. As Cameron and a growing band of Tory backbenchers have begun to suggest, that differential treatment offends against basic notions of fairness: that families with the same circumstances should receive the same level of help from the state. It's extraordinary that the coalition is still having this argument now. It was evident from the moment the chancellor announced the policy in autumn 2010 that it would throw up exactly these anomalies. Yet like Gordon Brown's disastrous abolition of the 10p tax rate – overshadowed in the headlines at the time by the reduction in the basic rate of income tax it paid for – politicians have failed to focus until the moment for implementation is near, and the tide of letters from furious constituents has started to flood in. The fact is, there's no easy solution: income tax is administered completely separately for each earner – something women have long campaigned for – and there's no system of joint taxation in place to provide the kind of data necessary for full-blown means-testing. Household income as a whole is only assessed when families come into contact with the tax credits or benefits system. But many of those who will lose out here are not in that category; and the Tories want to dismantle the means-tested tax credit system, not extend it into fresh areas. The beauty of the "cliff edge", from the Treasury's point of view, is its simplicity, and the fact that it piggy-backs on information the state already holds. A more nuanced alternative would be likely to impose considerable administrative costs. Perhaps the vehemence of the row, and the difficulty of resolving it, should point towards the fact that attacking child benefit is the wrong place to start dismantling the welfare state, even in these painfully austere times. Maintaining democratic support for a modern, flexible welfare system means that it shouldn't just redistribute from the wealthy to the needy, but help share the burden of saving for the leanest times of our lives. That way almost everyone contributes, and almost everyone gets help when they most need it. That's the justification for establishing a generous flat-rate state pension, instead of disincentivising saving by means-testing every last penny, an idea Iain Duncan-Smith has enthusiastically embraced. By that logic, everyone should also get a helping hand with one of the toughest and most socially important jobs there is: bringing up children. And as for where else to find the money, taxing higher-rate earners on their assets – their million-pound homes, for example, if Cable gets his way with a "mansion tax", or the pension savings on which they currently receive more tax relief than lower earners – might be a better place to start.

webTitle: Boris Johnson youth violence strategy: 'sabotaged' and 'a shambles' his expert advisors say

fields.bodyText: Boris Johnson's undertaking to get to grips with knife and youth crime was one of the most welcome of his pledges during the last mayoral campaign. Since moving in to City Hall he's put time and energy into delivering. But what has really been achieved? Three members of an advisory group Boris set up to help him tackle serious youth violence have made known their disappointment with his administration's approach to the issue. The educationalist and social investment consultant Professor Gus John describes the mayoral strategy as "directionless" and "a shambles." Leadership coach and social policy adviser Viv Ahmun believes the group's work was undermined by people around the mayor. Richard Taylor, the father of Damilola Taylor who was killed when aged 10 in south London in November 2000, was "hugely frustrated" by his experience with the mayor's regime. The mayor's expert advisory group (MEAG) was formed at Boris's instigation in July 2010 in response to concerns that his Time For Action programme aimed at deterring young people from crime was failing to address the specific needs of black youths in London, who are over-represented in crime statistics both as perpetrators and victims of violent and other offences. The other members of the MEAG were Bevan Powell of the Metropolitan Black Police Association, community activist churchman Nims Obunge of the Tottenham-based Peace Alliance and Ray Lewis, who Boris had begun to rehabilitate following his forced resignation as his deputy for youth in July 2008. Following a number of meetings and discussions with Boris, his then chief of staff Sir Simon Milton (who died in April 2011) and his policing deputy Kit Malthouse - who Boris has since appointed to head the new Mayor's Office for Policing and Crime - a report came out of the MEAG in January 2011 which set out the group's "initial consolidated views" and recommendations for developing "an effective, long-term approach to addressing and preventing the serious youth violence that has particularly impacted on the Black community in London." The report argued that, "There remains widespread official confusion about the nature of the problem and what works in practice," and contrasted the failures of "top down" public sector provision and "community safety and policing policy" and with emerging research showing that community-based, "bottom up" interventions could help to diagnose and address the issue. It described a programme of research to enhance understanding of serious youth violence as being "essential" and said that any failure to accurately gauge what types of interventions work "will result in serious public health and community safety issues." The report stressed the importance of engaging local people in the strategy, and listed educational underachievement, the need to "develop a narrative which addresses the challenges of families beyond current 'broken Britain' thinking," and the alienating psychological impact of stop-and search on innocent young black people among key issues for close attention. Lewis, Ahmun, Obunge, Powell and Taylor all signed up to the report, but Professor John, whose previous contributions it acknowledges, had resigned from the MEAG the previous month. He says it, "Lacked credibility, purpose, integrity, everything." In his letter of resignation to Boris he wrote: "From the outside, the continued operation of the group in its current form looks like a cynical exercise of going through the motions." John, who has previously run youth services for the Inner London Education Authority and had recently been involved with Channel 4's Street Weapons report, says he agreed to help Boris in the hope that the mayor would listen to a "steering group, monitoring his strategy." But he soon concluded that Boris, "Really only wanted people who would say what he wanted to hear." Though John thought some of the City Hall officers involved very competent, he describes Malthouse and Milton as "dinosaurs," and "very dismissive." He says, for example, that his suggestion that Boris hold a youth conference in keeping with a "bottom up" approach was dismissed. John is also critical of the composition of the group, which he says was in theory to be "a conduit for community input," yet contained no women or young people. He feels there was confusion and conflict from the start about its role, with different members having very different ideas about what their contribution should be, and queried the transparency of criteria by which people were deemed eligible to join the group. John says that at one point the name of Shaun Bailey, the unsuccessful Conservative parliamentary candidate for the Hammersmith constituency in 2010, began to be included in correspondence to MEAG members without any explanation. He says that Boris and Ray Lewis had decided to bring Bailey in. "It was as though people were being added to the group on a whim," John says. It took until mid-December 2010 – five months after the MEAG was formed – for Lewis, who chaired the group for the mayor, to produce a strategy document for discussion. John says that after giving a verbal assessment of it Lewis responded to his criticisms by saying the document was not really his work but put together by "one of the girls in the office," at his Eastside Young Leaders Academy in Newham. "We'd been waiting for this for months," John said, "and when it turned up it was weak and baseless. It didn't even have a name or a date on it." John also produced his own discussion paper, but resigned from the MEAG on Christmas Eve 2010, a few days after a meeting with Boris. "I didn't want to give it any credibility by being associated with it," he says. Viv Ahmun says he was approached by Lewis shortly after Boris's election in May 2008, when Lewis was the mayor's full-time "deputy for youth." Although Ahmun had previously assisted Ken Livingstone on youth issues he says he had "no problem," with doing the same for his successor, whom he already knew because their children had attended the same primary school. He recalls attending an early meeting with Kit Malthouse, who was then deputy chair of the now defunct Metropolitan Police Authority, where he says he was told that the focus of police action on serious youth violence would be stop-and-search and enforcement. Following Lewis's resignation as youth deputy in July 2008 after investigations into his past culminated in the discovery that he was not, as he had claimed, a justice of the peace, Ahmun says he had no further contact with City Hall until the summer of 2010. He felt that concerns he had raised about the forthcoming Time for Action programme had not been heeded. But he says he received a phone call from Boris, who told him that he agreed with critics who said that Time for Action wasn't working for the key group affected - young black Londoners - and asked him to join the advisory group to help put that right. "I told him I would be happy to help if he was serious," Ahmun said, and stresses that he happily gave his time for free. However, he describes the ensuing months as, "A very painful period because there was so much resistance to what we were doing." He says he believes the group's efforts were, "Sabotaged behind the scenes," by infuential members of the mayor's team. Ahmun says that he continued to provide unpaid help with starting the mayor's mentoring scheme – which had become a key strand of Time for Action – but severed all ties after the controversial decision not to award the contract to deliver it to a consortium of black voluntary sector organisations, despite its bid twice being judged the best by a mayoral decision panel. "It had become very political and messed up," Ahmun says. By this time the MEAG had effectively ceased to exist. Asked to comment on its work and the views of disappointed members City Hall issued the following statement: The Mayor and his team met on a number of occasions with a small group of individuals to discuss methods of tackling youth violence. These meetings resulted in an ambitious programme of local engagement - the Mayor's Community Conversations Programme - where the Mayor joined community leaders and local people across seven boroughs to discuss solutions to violence. The Mayor has thanked the group for their tremendous contributions and he remains committed to working on long term solutions to youth crime. A statement issued on Richard Taylor's behalf by the Damilola Taylor Trust says that "Richard was hugely frustrated by the inability of City Hall to deliver on its promises of engagement with the youth of London especially in the areas of tackling youth crime," despite feeling "from the outset that the Mayor was entirely serious about [the advisory group's] objectives." The statement expresses regret over "in-fighting and disagreements," within the group and says that Taylor thinks the mayor's "hands are largely tied," by City Hall's being "too bureaucratic for its own good," resulting in a failure to achieve what it promises, for all its power and influence. The statement concludes: "City Hall has never delivered positive results in tackling youth crime since it first took power over London in the same year that Damilola died." Something for Ken Livingstone to reflect on there too.
fields.trailText: Three members of an expert panel set up by the London mayor to help reach back youth have made known their disappointment with his administration
